profileText: A Representative from Oregon; born near Caldwell, Noble County, Ohio, May 13, 1849; moved with his parents over the Old Oregon Trail in 1851 and settled on a homestead near Lebanon, Linn County, Oreg.; attended the country schools, Santiam Academy, and Willamette University, Oregon; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Portland, Oreg., in 1875; member of the State senate from Multnomah district 1876-1880; elected as a Republican to the Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Congresses (March 4, 1881-March 3, 1885); declined to be a candidate for renomination in 1884; resumed the practice of law in Portland, Oreg.; judge of the State circuit court 1897-1907; appointed by the circuit judges to superintend the construction of the Burnside Bridge over the Willamette River at Portland; director of the Portland public schools for five years; died in Portland, Oreg., February 22, 1933; interment in Lone Fir Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In William P. Lord papers, 1894-1903, 2 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Includes letters from George to Governor Lord regarding various political issues. Finding aid in repository.

researchRecord.name: 1882, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Benjamin Alvord to M.C. George, March 7, 1882 to accompany a map "Rough Sketches from Notes of the Marches [?] by Expeditions in the Summer of 1864" by Bowen [?], not present.

researchRecord.name: 1882-1933, 2 folders.
researchRecord.description: The collection includes: photocopied newspaper clippings about M. C. George; typescript document "Secrets for a Healthy Life," 49 pp; Letters from M. C. George; Letters to M. C. George from: P.W. Marx, City Engineer of The Dalles, Oregon, Albert Tozier, Edward R. Geary, Benjamin Alvord, etc; Typescript copy of a letter on United States Senate stationery recommending the appointment of Judge M. C. George, 1 p, 1905; Manuscript financial records, 1 p; Typescript biographical notes; Typescript document "The Commercial Future of Portland and the Great Columbia Basin," address before the Columbia and Snake River Waterway Association, Kennewick Washington, by M. C. George, 23 pp, September 2, 1913.

researchRecord.name: 1867-1930, 2 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of M.C. George include manuscript addresses, mostly undated, given before such groups as the Linn County Agricultural Association, Sons of the American Revolution, American Medical Association, and Oregon Bar Association. There is also a folder of printed addresses by George. Two folders contain essays and letters to newspapers, written by George. In 1925, George compiled a travel brochure describing scenes along the Columbia River Highway, The Columbia Highway Booklet (Portland, 1923). The collection contains correspondence regarding the booklet, a manuscript, and a finished copy of the booklet. In 1925, the Great Northern Railway Co. suggested that George prepare a similar booklet describing scenes along its right-of-way on the Columbia. A manuscript (carbon copy) and correspondence with the railway, 1925-1929 (included in the collection), is all that came of the project. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1884, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Edward R. Geary to M.C. George, January 5, 1884, concerning Henry Villard's "misfortune" and the Northern Pacific Railroad.

researchRecord.name: 1884, 1 folder.
researchRecord.description: The collection contains a letter dated April 11, 1884, from Matthew Paul Deady, of Portland, Oregon to Melvin C. George, of Washington, D.C. regarding the judicial salary bill.
